New privacy bill would end law enforcement practice of buying data from brokers@tayhatmaker3/21/2021

A new bill known as the Fourth Amendment is Not for Sale Act would seal up a loophole that intelligence and law enforcement agencies use to obtain troves of sensitive and identifying information to which they wouldn’t otherwise have legal access. The new legislation, proposed by Senators Ron …

<div id="root">
	<div><!-- duplicate React-root div for styling -->
	<div class="content">
		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">New privacy bill would end law enforcement practice of buying data from brokers</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/taylor-hatmaker/">
			Taylor Hatmaker		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
							<a href="https://twitter.com/tayhatmaker">@tayhatmaker</a>
				<span class="text--green"> / </span>
						1 year		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/surveillance.png?w=711" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary">A new bill known as the Fourth Amendment is Not for Sale Act would seal up a loophole that intelligence and law enforcement agencies use to obtain troves of sensitive and identifying information to which they wouldn’t otherwise have legal access.</p>
<p>The new legislation, proposed by Senators Ron Wyden (D-OR) and Rand Paul (R-KY), would require government agencies to obtain a court order <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2018/05/27/vermont-passes-first-first-law-to-crack-down-on-data-brokers/">to access data from brokers</a>. Court orders are already required when the government seeks analogous data from mobile providers and tech platforms.</p>
<p>“There’s no reason information scavenged by data brokers should be treated differently than the same data held by your phone company or email provider,” Wyden said. Wyden describes the loophole as a way that police and other agencies buy data to “end-run the Fourth Amendment.”</p>
<p>Paul criticized the government for using the current data broker loophole to circumvent Americans’ constitutional rights. “The Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable search and seizure ensures that the liberty of every American cannot be violated on the whims, or financial transactions, of every government officer,” Paul said.</p>
<p>Critically, the bill would also ban law enforcement agencies from buying data on Americans when it was obtained through hacking, violations of terms of service or “from a user’s account or device.”</p>
<p>That bit highlights the questionable practices of Clearview AI, a deeply controversial tech company that sells access to a facial recognition search engine. Clearview’s platform collects pictures of faces scraped from across the web, including social media sites, and sells access to that data to <a href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanmac/facial-recognition-local-police-clearview-ai-table">police departments around the country</a> and <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/14/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020/">federal agencies like ICE</a>.</p>
<div class="embed breakout">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="t9LlnLMEal"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/14/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020/">Clearview AI landed a new facial recognition contract with ICE</a></p></blockquote><div class="piano-inline-promo"></div>
<p><iframe class="wp-embedded-content" sandbox="allow-scripts" security="restricted" style="position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);" title="“Clearview AI landed a new facial recognition contract with ICE” — TechCrunch" src="https://techcrunch.com/2020/08/14/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020/embed/#?secret=t9LlnLMEal" data-secret="t9LlnLMEal" width="800" height="450" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div>
<p>In scraping their sites for data to sell, Clearview has run afoul of just about every major social media platform’s terms of service. Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google have all denounced Clearview for using data culled from their services and some have even sent cease-and-desists ordering the data broker to stop.</p>
<p>The bill would also expand privacy laws to apply to infrastructure companies that own cell towers and data cables, seal up workarounds that allow intelligence agencies to obtain metadata from Americans’ international communications without review by a FISA court and ensure that agencies seek probable cause orders to obtain location and web browsing data.</p>
<p>The bill, embedded below, isn’t just some nascent proposal. It’s already attracted bipartisan support from a number of key co-sponsors, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Bernie Sanders on the Democratic side and Republicans Mike Lee and Steve Daines. A House version of the legislation was also introduced Wednesday.</p>
<p><iframe class="scribd_iframe_embed" src="https://www.scribd.com/embeds/504010291/content?start_page=1&view_mode&access_key=key-DedzWE7mpGBslNIRn3Lb"  data-auto-height="true" scrolling="no" id="scribd_504010291" width="100%" height="500" frameborder="0"></iframe>
		<div style="font-size:10px;text-align:center;width:100%"><a href="https://www.scribd.com/doc/504010291" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">View this document on Scribd</a></div></p>
<div class="embed breakout">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="DSnDHzD4Gw"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/09/data-brokers-tracking/">Data brokers track everywhere you go, but their days may be numbered</a></p></blockquote>
<p><iframe class="wp-embedded-content" sandbox="allow-scripts" security="restricted" style="position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);" title="“Data brokers track everywhere you go, but their days may be numbered” — TechCrunch" src="https://techcrunch.com/2020/07/09/data-brokers-tracking/embed/#?secret=DSnDHzD4Gw" data-secret="DSnDHzD4Gw" width="800" height="450" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div>
<div class="embed breakout">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="5iFo4CFbBT"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2021/04/20/whos-funding-privacy-tech/">Who’s funding privacy tech?</a></p></blockquote>
<p><iframe class="wp-embedded-content" sandbox="allow-scripts" security="restricted" style="position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);" title="“Who’s funding privacy tech?” — TechCrunch" src="https://techcrunch.com/2021/04/20/whos-funding-privacy-tech/embed/#?secret=5iFo4CFbBT" data-secret="5iFo4CFbBT" width="800" height="450" frameborder="0" marginwidth="0" marginheight="0" scrolling="no"></iframe></div>
<p> </p>

Sponsored post defaults","conditions":{"post_types":["tc_sponsored_post"]},"placements":{"leaderboard":"963872468","rightrail1":"963872467","mobile_leaderboard":"963872466","mobile_footer":"963909570"}},{"name":"Run of site \/ fallback","conditions":[],"placements":{"native_inriver":"93501877","native_mobile_inriver":"93501878","leaderboard":"93484975","amp_leaderboard":"963912137","rightrail1":"93484976","native_rightrail1":"963912090","native_mobile_footer":"963923619","native_rightrail2":"963913332","native_midarticle":"963922183","native_mobile_midarticle":"963922184","amp_footer":"93523784","amp_midarticle":"963923315","rightrail2":"963913913","article_footer":"963908972","mobile_leaderboard":"93484974","mobile_footer":"93484973","midarticle1":"963923871","xl_midarticle1":"963923870","midarticle2":"963923883","xl_midarticle2":"963923882","mobile_midarticle1":"963923872","mobile_midarticle2":"963923884"}}]},"assetURI":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/themes\/techcrunch-2017","breaking":"","live_event":"0","feature_islands":{"homepage":[{"id":2312721,"date":"2022-05-05T05:30:42","date_gmt":"2022-05-05T12:30:42","guid":{"rendered":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/?p=2312721"},"modified":"2022-05-05T08:00:10","modified_gmt":"2022-05-05T15:00:10","slug":"shopify-acquires-shipping-logistics-startup-deliverr-for-2-1b","status":"publish","type":"post","link":"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/05\/shopify-acquires-shipping-logistics-startup-deliverr-for-2-1b\/","title":{"rendered":"Shopify acquires shipping logistics startup Deliverr for $2.1B"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Shopify today <a href=\"https:\/\/news.shopify.com\/oh-ship-shopify-to-acquire-deliverr-for-21b-building-the-future-of-global-logistics-for-independent-brands\">announced<\/a> that it will acquire Deliverr, a San Francisco, California-based ecommerce fulfillment startup, for $2.1 billion in cash and stock. The deal, rumors of which were <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-04-20\/shopify-said-to-be-in-talks-to-buy-tech-startup-deliverr\">reported<\/a> in April by Bloomberg, is the largest acquisition in Shopify’s history, and Shopify founder and CEO Tobi L\u00fctke says that it will enable the company to create an “end-to-end logistics” platform for millions of merchants.<\/p>\n<p>“Our goal is to not only level the playing field for independent businesses, but tilt it in their favor — turning their size and agility into their superpower,” L\u00fctke said in a blog post detailing the acquisition. “Together with Deliverr, SFN will give millions of growing businesses access to a simple, powerful logistics platform that will allow them to make their customers happy over and over again.”<\/p>\n<p>Specifically, Shopify says that Deliverr will combine with with Shopify Fulfillment Network (SFN) — Shopify’s fulfillment service that merchants can use to store inventory and fulfill orders — to strengthen SFN\u2019s merchant inventory management capabilities. Deliverr’s technology will also power Shop Promise, a new service that will provide customers two-day and next-day delivery, as well as expanded options for storage, freight, inventory preparation, and returns.<\/p>\n<p>“Our technology and expertise in inventory management, inventory placement, and demand chain combines perfectly with Shopify\u2019s roadmap, enabling us to now build an end-to-end logistics platform together,\u201d Deliverr cofounder and CEO Harish Abbott said in a statement. “Shopify has been building the future of merchant-first fulfillment solutions, and our team has a track record of helping businesses of all sizes streamline their operations. We\u2019re excited to join Shopify in their mission to make commerce better for everyone while democratizing shipping and fulfillment for independent entrepreneurs.”<\/p>\n<h2>Road to acquisition<\/h2>\n<p>Deliverr was cofounded by former Symphony Commerce colleagues Abbott and Michael Krakaris in 2017, and had raised $490.9 million in capital prior to the Shopify purchase. The <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/11\/22\/deliverr-inventory-customers\/\">last<\/a> funding round, a $240 million Series F led by Tiger Global, valued the company at $2 billion post-money.<\/p>\n<p>Using predictive analytics and machine learning, Deliverr, which rents out warehouse space and uses warehouses\u2019 fulfillment departments to pick and pack ecommerce orders, <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">anticipates the demand for products based on geography and other variables. The platform then uses the analysis to “pre-position” items close to areas of demand, stocking items across its network of warehouses and sort centers and determining the best delivery method to ship to customers.<\/span><\/p>\n<p>Under the acquisition agreement, Shopify said it will pay about 80% of the purchase price in cash (~$1.68 billion) and 20% (~$420 million) in Shopify Class A shares. As with many tech giants, Shopify has Class A shares that get one vote per share and Class B shares with several votes per share, with Class B shareholders having a controlling position.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Given Deliverr’s financials, is that on the light side of M&A? TechCrunch’s resident deal guru, Alex Wilhelm, doesn’t think so. He pointed out to me that the startup market valuation cycle was near an all-time high last November, meaning Deliverr raised at or around a peak while managing to defend this price in middle-early 2022. Of course, the deal could squeeze early investors if the company’s final round included provisions that ensured final investors would receive a set minimum return, but this remains to be seen.<\/p>\n<h2>Broader logistics strategy<\/h2>\n<p>Shopify’s Deliverr acquisition follows close on the heels of its $450 million <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2019\/09\/09\/shopify-buys-warehouse-automation-tech-developer-6-river-systems-for-450-million\/\">purchase<\/a> of 6 River Systems, which developed cloud-based software and mobile robots specifically designed for shipping and fulfillment. SFN, 6 River Systems, and Deliverr will form a broader logistics unit within Shopify under the group’s newly appointed CEO, Aaron Brown, who has led SFN since 2020.<\/p>\n<p>Fast shipping has become increasingly desirable for merchants as the pandemic impacts nearly every aspect of the supply chain — and as more retailers migrate online, spurred by pandemic-related restrictions. Sellers see automation as means to this end. One in three claim have integrated services like those offered by Deliverr into their supply chain management processes and one in four is working toward that goal, a <a href=\"https:\/\/www.symphonyretailai.com\/study-shows-half-of-retail-leaders-are-embracing-ai-to-transform-the-supply-chain\/\">survey<\/a> from Symphony RetailAI found.<\/p>\n<p>A 2021 PwC <a href=\"https:\/\/www.pwc.com\/gx\/en\/industries\/consumer-markets\/consumer-insights-survey.html\">poll<\/a> found that 41% of shoppers are willing to pay a premium for same-day delivery. On the flip side, <a href=\"https:\/\/hbr.org\/2021\/05\/how-e-commerce-fits-into-retails-post-pandemic-future\">only<\/a> 20% of consumers were willing to forgive retailers for delivery disruptions due to supply chain issues in 2021 — highlighting the pressure on retailers to deliver.<\/p>\n<p>Statista <a href=\"https:\/\/www.statista.com\/statistics\/1181996\/supply-chain-management-market-size-worldwide\/\">predicts<\/a> that the supply chain management market could be worth $30.91 billion by 2026, up from $19.58 billion in 2022. Venture firms invested more than $11 billion in the sector last year, <a href=\"https:\/\/news.crunchbase.com\/news\/supply-chain-vc-startup-funding\/\">according<\/a> to Crunchbase data.<\/p>\n<p>In its <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2022-05-05\/shopify-sinks-after-earnings-miss-and-2-1-billion-deliverr-deal\">most recent fiscal quarter<\/a>, Shopify missed analysts’ estimates, posting $1.2 billion in revenue — short of the $1.25 billion expected. Evidently, the company sees logistics as its next major profit driver, not to mention a key piece in its fight against Amazon, which recently launched a program a program, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/21\/amazon-is-primed-for-online-domination\/\">Buy with Prime<\/a>, that allows Amazon Prime members to shop from merchants’ stores and access free delivery and returns benefits.<\/p>\n<p>“Retailers have been engaged in a race to the bottom with delivery options for years, but it really got heightened after the pandemic began, when digital commerce sales picked up massively. There\u2019s an interesting competition heating up between Amazon and Shopify, with Amazon recently encroaching on Shopify\u2019s turf through Buy With Prime and Shopify certainly taking aim at taking a larger share of the online retail opportunity,” Gartner analyst Matt Moorut told TechCrunch via email. “The Deliverr tie up promises to add value to retailers that are already using Shopify to power their carts … If Shopify can integrate Deliverr\u2019s offering into their existing platform, it promises to give a lot more security to online retailers that they\u2019ll be able to continue selling, whatever further disruptions lie ahead.”<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"4bbSKYJNfl\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/05\/deliverrs-nearly-flat-exit-price-isnt-as-bad-as-it-looks\/\">Deliverr’s nearly flat exit price isn’t as bad as it looks<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Deliverr’s nearly flat exit price isn’t as bad as it looks” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/05\/05\/deliverrs-nearly-flat-exit-price-isnt-as-bad-as-it-looks\/embed\/#?secret=n6TUSgnhgB#?secret=4bbSKYJNfl\" data-secret=\"4bbSKYJNfl\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Shopify today announced that it will acquire Deliverr, a San Francisco, California-based ecommerce fulfillment startup, for $2.1 billion in cash and stock. open source tool used by Google, Meta and MIT is helping rethink knowledge management"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><a href=\"https:\/\/logseq.com\/\">Logseq<\/a> founder Tienson Qin takes a lot of notes about his work. He also likes to draw together with his six year old daughter on an iPad, and he found that the notes tool he had been using for years doesn\u2019t run on the tablet. So like all enterprising engineers, he decided to build a new tool that does.<\/p>\n<p>Being able to share drawings with his child may have been an initial motivation for Qin, but he also wanted to build a tool for connecting his work documents in a kind of internal web that could be shared across any device, either for an individual or a team of users.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cI needed to make my life easier, and to connect my notes so I could build my thoughts incrementally and connect them together. So it started as a solo project, and now we’re expanding that, and it will be a company that we will build a team around,\u201d Qin told me.<\/p>\n<p>The idea is not unlike the web itself, which lets you connect related information across systems, but in this case, it\u2019s about sharing knowledge and research semantically for individuals and teams. Eventually, this has the potential to be a system for more easily managing knowledge inside an organization, a goal that has been attempted for years, but so far has never succeeded completely.<\/p>\n<p>Qin found that existing note tools like Evernote and Notion didn\u2019t connect and organize related documents the way he needed, relying too much on a hierarchical file structure. \u201cLogseq is entirely different. Those platforms store text in single documents. Logseq stores inter-connected information in infinite graphs. This means that you can traverse a research volume or dataset or CRM in Logseq by browsing these interconnected graphs.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>That\u2019s because the open source tool is built on a graph database, to allow the system to build semantic connections between documents, whether notes, research, information or PDF markups. \u201cYou have a set of keywords, and you can connect those ideas together through keywords and what we call a reference so you can reference this page or this idea in another page and build the connections in this way,\u201d he said.<\/p>\n<p>It\u2019s also designed to allow the development of plug-ins to add elements that don\u2019t exist in the base product such as Google Calendar integration and a tagging tool to extend the capabilities of the base tool.<\/p>\n<p>What\u2019s more, Qin says the project has put a priority on privacy and the company doesn\u2019t have access to any notes on the system, which are all stored locally. The company only launched the tool in open source in October, but reports that large organizations like Google, Meta and MIT have been using Logseq.<\/p>\n<p>For now the product just consists of an editor, which is Markup language-based, but they are working on additional pieces including real-time collaboration in which multiple users can work on the same document at the same time like multiple people working on a Google Doc. That capability is expected to be ready soon.<\/p>\n<p>The idea is so compelling that Qin has raised $4.1M in initial capital led by Andreessen Horowitz along with the CEOs of Stripe, Github and Shopify. Users including teams at Google Brain, IDEO, Meta, Tesla, MIT, Stanford and Harvard also contributed to the round. The fact that users are contributing is pretty unusual, according to the company.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"pyCjlnJlxF\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/20\/weavits-new-app-wants-to-be-a-shazam-for-your-thoughts\/\">Weavit’s new app wants to be a ‘Shazam for your thoughts’<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Weavit’s new app wants to be a ‘Shazam for your thoughts’” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/01\/20\/weavits-new-app-wants-to-be-a-shazam-for-your-thoughts\/embed\/#?secret=JufxkpvdmV#?secret=pyCjlnJlxF\" data-secret=\"pyCjlnJlxF\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Logseq founder Tienson Qin takes a lot of notes about his work. Go is shutting down in August"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">YouTube Go is shutting down beginning this August, Google has <a href=\"https:\/\/support.google.com\/youtube\/thread\/162222567\/youtube-go-is-going-away-in-august-of-this-year?hl=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">announced<\/a> this week. The lightweight Android app first <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2016\/09\/27\/google-youtube-go-app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">launched in 2016<\/a> and features offline viewing and nearby sharing. Like other apps designed for emerging markets, YouTube Go includes a suite of features that take in consideration the high costs of data, poor signal strength, and the prevalent use of SD cards on Android devices. YouTube Go first launched in India and<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/02\/01\/googles-data-friendly-app-youtube-go-expands-to-over-130-countries-now-supports-higher-quality-videos\/\"> later became available<\/a> in over 130 countries worldwide.<\/p>\n<p>The company notes that since 2016, it has invested in improvements to the main YouTube app that make it perform better in emerging markets, while also delivering a better user experience. For example, the company has improved performance for entry-level devices or those that watch YouTube on slower networks. YouTube also plans to build out additional user controls that help to decrease usage for viewers with limited data.<\/p>\n<p>YouTube recommends that YouTube Go users install the main YouTube app or visit the browser version of the platform. The company notes that the main YouTube app provides a better overall user experience in comparison to YouTube Go, and that it has user-requested features that aren’t available on YouTube Go, such as the ability to comment, post, create content and use dark theme.<\/p>\n<p>“Using the main YouTube app, YouTube Go users will be able to participate in creation and community and have access to an overall improved user experience,” the company said in a <a href=\"https:\/\/support.google.com\/youtube\/thread\/162222567\/youtube-go-is-going-away-in-august-of-this-year?hl=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">blog post<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>One of the main features of YouTube Go is the ability to download and save videos for offline viewing later, which was meant to make it easier for users who may not have internet access at all times to still be able to access videos on the platform. Although YouTube’s main app does support offline videos, the feature is locked behind the company’s Premium subscription. It looks like YouTube’s decision to shut down Go may be a way for it to push users towards its Premium offering, which is currently priced at $12 per month in the United States and 129 rupees a month in India.<\/p>\n<p>YouTube Go isn’t the only lightweight app to shut down in recent years, as Facebook <a href=\"https:\/\/www.macrumors.com\/2020\/08\/12\/facebook-kills-off-facebook-lite-app\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">shut down Facebook Lite<\/a> in 2020. Facebook Lite launched in 2015 to reach users in emerging markets but was later shut down due to poor adoption and users were told to use the main Facebook app instead. In addition, Google, which is YouTube’s parent company, also recently <a href=\"https:\/\/pocketnow.com\/google-shutting-down-chrome-lite-mode\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">shut down the Chrome Lite mode<\/a> feature that was designed to help users save internet.<\/p>\n<p>With low-end smartphones getting better both in terms of hardware and software over the years, it makes sense for digital giants like Google and Facebook to shut down their lightweight apps as they’re no longer as necessary as they were a few years ago.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"RQfnJc4zfB\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/02\/01\/googles-data-friendly-app-youtube-go-expands-to-over-130-countries-now-supports-higher-quality-videos\/\">Google’s data-friendly app YouTube Go expands to over 130 countries, now supports higher quality videos<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Google’s data-friendly app YouTube Go expands to over 130 countries, now supports higher quality videos” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/02\/01\/googles-data-friendly-app-youtube-go-expands-to-over-130-countries-now-supports-higher-quality-videos\/embed\/#?secret=2Tzph11vaA#?secret=RQfnJc4zfB\" data-secret=\"RQfnJc4zfB\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>YouTube Go is shutting down beginning this August, Google has announced this week. Binance and a16z back Elon Musk’s $44 billion Twitter bid"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">A group of nearly two dozen investors including Sequoia Capital, Andreessen Horowitz, crypto exchange Binance and asset management firm Fidelity has invested over $7.1 billion to back the Tesla and SpaceX chief executive <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2022\/04\/25\/twitter-accepts-elon-musks-43b-acquisition-offer\/\">Elon Musk’s $44 billion bid to acquire Twitter<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, who is also an investor in Tesla, delivered the largest check, at $1 billion, a Thursday filing revealed. Sequoia has chipped in $800 million, VyCapital $700 million, Binance financed $500 million, and Andreessen Horowitz has invested $400 million, the <a href=\"https:\/\/www.sec.gov\/Archives\/edgar\/data\/0001494730\/000110465922056055\/tm2214608-1_sc13da.htm\">amended 13D filing said<\/a>. Notably, no investor has put in more than $1 billion and large PE firms are still MIA.<\/p>\n<p>“Elon is the one person we know and perhaps the only person in the world who has the courage, brilliance, and skills to fix all of these and build the public square that we all hoped for and deserve,” said Ben Horowitz, co-founder and general partner at Andreessen Horowitz, in a <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bhorowitz\/status\/1522198627128553472\">tweet<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>“We invested, because we believe in Ev and Jack\u2019s vision to connect the world and we believe in Elon\u2019s brilliance to finally make it what it was meant to be. While Twitter has great promise as a public square, it suffers from a myriad of difficult issues ranging from bots to abuse to censorship. backing Musk in the fresh financing includes Qatar, which as you may remember, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.amnesty.org\/en\/latest\/news\/2020\/01\/qatar-repressive-new-law-further-curbs-freedom-of-expression\/\">has a poor track record with free speech<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Saudi Arabia’s takeover by Musk, the disclosure said.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Musk said he is engaging with certain additional existing shareholders including Twitter co-founder and former chief executive Jack Dorsey to give them the option to roll over their shares.<\/p>\n<p>As a result of the new investment, Musk said the margin loan of $12.5 billion he had received from Morgan Stanley and other banks has been cut to $6.25 billion. startups are on a long journey to consumer markets, but these 5 VCs are taking the ride"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">\u201cLike a pressure<\/span> cooker, COVID blew the lid off what was a simmering mental health crisis for over a decade,\u201d VC Tim Schlidt told TechCrunch.<\/p>\n<p>According to the World Health Organization, the global prevalence of anxiety and depression increased by a massive 25% in the first year of the pandemic. And when available treatment options <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2022\/04\/21\/well\/antidepressants-ssri-effectiveness.html\">showed their limits<\/a>, both the general public and regulators became more willing to look into alternatives \u2013 including psychedelics.<\/p>\n<p>Previously relegated to underground communities and rave culture, drugs like ketamine, MDMA (commonly known as ecstasy) and psilocybin are now being studied to develop therapies to treat everything from PTSD to cluster headaches.<\/p>\n<p>“Today, there are 400+ ketamine clinics in the U.S., and over $200m has been raised over the last two years to open even more,” Dina Burkitbayeva, founder of PsyMed Ventures, said. “Many of these clinics will be sites for MDMA- and psilocybin-assisted therapies, if they are approved, and treatments derived from other molecules as they become available.”<\/p>\n<p>A more favorable regulatory and social landscape is helping psychedelic startups gain a foothold, but they still have to walk a tightrope that\u2019s susceptible to the vagaries of market sentiment. \u201cWhile there has been a lot of focus on mental health and the promise of psychedelics to be truly disruptive, not all the hype is warranted or justified. In fact, there are many investors who have been hurt by the early hype-driven public markets,\u201d said Sa\u2019ad Shah, managing partner of Noetic Fund.<\/p>\n<p>Burkitbayeva, Shah, and Schlidt are three of the five investors we interviewed for this deep dive. Each of them has an investment thesis that strongly overlaps with applications of psychedelics.<\/p>\n<p>Indeed, investor interest around psychedelic startups has mushroomed in recent years, attracting interest from generalist investors. But as public market sentiment fluctuates, specialized VCs seem more likely to stick around for the whole trip.<\/p>\n<p>Ready for the trip? Meet our interviewees:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/tim-schlidt-50538255\/\">Tim Schlidt<\/a>, co-founder and partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.palosanto.vc\/\">Palo Santo<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/kukulabanze\">Ryan Zurrer<\/a>, founder, <a href=\"https:\/\/vine.vc\/\">Vine Ventures<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/dina-burkitbayeva-93950b65\">Dina Burkitbayeva<\/a>, founder, <a href=\"https:\/\/psymed.ventures\/\">PsyMed Ventures<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/clara-burtenshaw-5b184aa7\/\">Clara Burtenshaw<\/a>, partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.neokuma.co\/\">Neo Kuma Ventures<\/a><\/li>\n<li><a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/sa-ad-shah-a650441b7\/\">Sa’ad Shah<\/a>, managing partner, <a href=\"https:\/\/noeticfund.com\/\">Noetic Fund<\/a><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<hr \/>\n<h2>Tim Schlidt, co-founder and partner, Palo Santo<\/h2>\n<p><strong>Which applications of psychedelics are you most excited about, both in mental health and outside of it?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Outside of depression, anxiety and PTSD (the standard mood disorders we see targeted by psychedelics), the application of psychedelics for OCD is quite compelling. Based on work out of Yale, there appears to be little to no psychotherapy needed, as severe manifestations of OCD appear to be more like a motor disorder than one with a psychological underpinning.<\/p>\n<p>Additionally, psychedelics therapies for a range of substance use disorders are showing great promise. In particular, there has been compelling data around psilocybin for smoking cessation and even alcohol use disorder. While not considered a classic psychedelic, ibogaine has been effective in extirpating all symptoms of opioid use disorder after one session. So we are quite confident that psychedelics will emerge as effective therapies for treating a range of addictions.<\/p>\n<p>Outside of mental health, I am most fascinated by the application of psychedelics for inflammatory disorders. Based on the seminal work of Charles Nichols, certain psychedelic compounds appear to be potently anti-inflammatory at very low doses.<\/p>\n<p>Besides having broad applications across a range of inflammatory disorders, it also opens up a new mechanism underlying inflammatory pathways. Given how low the doses are required to be to achieve anti-inflammatory endpoints, the commercial viability of anti-inflammatories is dramatically higher, as they could be administered at subhallucinogenic doses.<\/p>\n<p>Another field of inquiry outside mental health is neuropathic pain. We are seeing some exploration of psychedelics for fibromyalgia as well as uses for cluster headaches and migraines.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What are you more bullish about: Companies directly involved in developing and\/or delivering psychedelics, or ancillary and infrastructure companies?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We are most excited by drug developers. We believe there are many shortcomings to current psychedelics, such as neurotoxicity, potential cardiac liability, inconsistent subjective experiences, and long durations. Next-generation drugs will improve on these qualities in order to make better, more commercially viable drugs.<\/p>\n<p>Additionally, the IP around these opportunities will be far more defensible, as they will be new chemical entities (NCEs). Research on psychedelics was stalled for decades due to DEA scheduling, but capabilities in the fields of pharmacology and medicinal chemistry advanced significantly during this \u201cdark age.\u201d As these molecules begin to see light again, we look forward to modern techniques being applied to produce drugs that have not changed much since the 1960s.<\/p>\n<p>Most ancillary services and technology will not take off until drugs commercialize, so we see few near-term opportunities in other verticals anyway. Additionally, are skeptic of why certain tech has to be \u201cpsychedelic.\u201d For example, there is little to nothing about EMR\/EHR, or clinic management software, that needs to be retrofitted for psychedelic therapies, and we foresee large incumbents such as an AdvancedMD being able to expand existing offerings into the psychedelic space.<\/p>\n<p>One piece of tech we do find quite compelling is patient data capture, or what is often called \u201cdigital phenotyping.\u201d While the applications of this can be beyond psychedelic therapies, we think companies like Ksana will have a formidable presence in clinical trials and post-market surveillance to track a range of outcomes for psychedelic therapies.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Can you talk about the impact of the pandemic on market prospects for psychedelic startups?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Like a pressure cooker, COVID blew the lid off what was a simmering mental health crisis for over a decade. Isolation and uncertainty dramatically increased patient population sizes across a range of mood disorders \u2014 data suggests ailments such as depression or anxiety doubled or even tripled through COVID. Nurse PTSD as well as PTSD from domestic violence increased markedly through the pandemic.<\/p>\n<p>Psychedelics are one of the rare cases where profit and impact work together synergistically. The large number of patients with mood disorders is indicative of a true humanitarian crisis that psychedelics hold the promise of addressing.<\/p>\n<p>Additionally, these large addressable markets present a business opportunity for investors who previously ignored investment in central nervous system disorders for decades.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Are regulatory or public sentiment issues a greater obstacle for psychedelic companies today?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>I\u2019d say regulatory, as these have to go through an FDA approval process. So that is the main hurdle psychedelic drugs will have to face. In large part, their advancement will be agnostic of public sentiment.<\/p>\n<p><strong>R&D-driven psychedelic companies usually need a lot of capital and tend to IPO early. Has the volatile climate for listed companies and public exits affected such companies more?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>To a degree, yes. We believe we will see a wash out of poorly capitalized companies that are primarily listed on Canadian stock exchanges. That said, we have seen most high-quality opportunities stay private, as they are able to fundraise in private markets and do not need to prematurely list.<\/p>\n<p>Current market conditions have certainly extended the runway required to achieve an IPO, but we are hopeful that upon achievement of Phase 2 readouts, companies will be able to publicly list, given how much a Phase 2 study de-risks an investment.<\/p>\n<p>The positive effect is that public markets have had a downstream effect of making private valuations much more reasonable than in 2021. With 55% of our fund left to deploy, we are quite eager to put money to work in this new environment.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Has M&A appetite evolved in recent months?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We have begun to see Big Pharma showing some interest in psychedelics, with Otsuka the most notable player to make investments in the space (Compass Pathways and Mindset Pharma). While no major M&A has occurred, we do think we will see large acquisitions once select drugs with strong IP achieve Phase 2 readouts.<\/p>\n<p>Cannabinoid biotech offers some glimmers of what could occur in psychedelics, with Jazz Pharma acquiring GW Pharma for $7.2 billion, and Pfizer buying Arena Pharma for $6.7 billion in part due to their cannabinoid portfolios.<\/p>\n<p>We believe appetite has evolved \u2014 psychedelic drug discovery businesses are now on Big Pharma\u2019s radar and will begin to be a more frequent topic of discussion in business development meetings at large pharmaceutical companies. We\u2019ll likely start seeing M&A activity pick up in 2026 as a range of compounds advance into the clinic.<\/p>\n<p><strong>What are the characteristics a founding team must have before you’d consider backing them?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>We seek teams that have deep biotech experience, with pedigrees comprising successful IND and NDA filings with the FDA. Furthermore, experience within central nervous system disorders and navigating the FDA\u2019s psychiatric and neurological divisions is a requirement. Years of research and understanding around the mechanism underlying classic psychedelics at the 5-HT2A receptor, or at minimum, background in research around the serotonin system helps a lot, too.<\/p>\n<p><strong>Should founders expect to meet you in person before you invest?<\/strong><\/p>\n<p>Not necessarily, but meeting in person does help. When we are leading a deal and taking a sizable stake, in-person meetings are of much greater importance. Venture partnerships last longer than many marriages, so it is important to meet and ensure it is a good match.<\/p>\n<h2>Ryan Zurrer, founder, Vine Ventures<\/h2>\n<p><strong>Which applications of privacy bill would end law enforcement practice of buying data from brokers"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">A new bill known as the Fourth Amendment is Not for Sale Act would seal up a loophole that intelligence and law enforcement agencies use to obtain troves of sensitive and identifying information to which they wouldn’t otherwise have legal access.<\/p>\n<p>The new legislation, proposed by Senators Ron Wyden (D-OR) and Rand Paul (R-KY), would require government agencies to obtain a court order <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/05\/27\/vermont-passes-first-first-law-to-crack-down-on-data-brokers\/\">to access data from brokers<\/a>. Court orders are already required when the government seeks analogous data from mobile providers and tech platforms.<\/p>\n<p>“There\u2019s no reason information scavenged by data brokers should be treated differently than the same data held by your phone company or email provider,” Wyden said. Wyden describes the loophole as a way that police and other agencies buy data to “end-run the Fourth Amendment.”<\/p>\n<p>Paul criticized the government for using the current data broker loophole to circumvent Americans’ constitutional rights. “The Fourth Amendment\u2019s protection against unreasonable search and seizure ensures that the liberty of every American cannot be violated on the whims, or financial transactions, of every government officer,” Paul said.<\/p>\n<p>Critically, the bill would also ban law enforcement agencies from buying data on Americans when it was obtained through hacking, violations of terms of service or “from a user\u2019s account or device.”<\/p>\n<p>That bit highlights the questionable practices of Clearview AI, a deeply controversial tech company that sells access to a facial recognition search engine. Clearview’s platform collects pictures of faces scraped from across the web, including social media sites, and sells access to that data to <a href=\"https:\/\/www.buzzfeednews.com\/article\/ryanmac\/facial-recognition-local-police-clearview-ai-table\">police departments around the country<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/14\/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020\/\">federal agencies like ICE<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"t9LlnLMEal\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/14\/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020\/\">Clearview AI landed a new facial recognition contract with ICE<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Clearview AI landed a new facial recognition contract with ICE” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/08\/14\/clearview-ai-ice-hsi-contract-2020\/embed\/#?secret=t9LlnLMEal\" data-secret=\"t9LlnLMEal\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>In scraping their sites for data to sell, Clearview has run afoul of just about every major social media platform’s terms of service. Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google have all denounced Clearview for using data culled from their services and some have even sent cease-and-desists ordering the data broker to stop.<\/p>\n<p>The bill would also expand privacy laws to apply to infrastructure companies that own cell towers and data cables, seal up workarounds that allow intelligence agencies to obtain metadata from Americans’ international communications without review by a FISA court and ensure that agencies seek probable cause orders to obtain location and web browsing data.<\/p>\n<p>The bill, embedded below, isn’t just some nascent proposal. It’s already attracted bipartisan support from a number of key co-sponsors, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Bernie Sanders on the Democratic side and Republicans Mike Lee and Steve Daines. A House version of the legislation was also introduced Wednesday.<\/p>\n<p><iframe class=\"scribd_iframe_embed\" src=\"https:\/\/www.scribd.com\/embeds\/504010291\/content?start_page=1&view_mode&access_key=key-DedzWE7mpGBslNIRn3Lb\"  data-auto-height=\"true\" scrolling=\"no\" id=\"scribd_504010291\" width=\"100%\" height=\"500\" frameborder=\"0\"><\/iframe>\n\t\t<div style=\"font-size:10px;text-align:center;width:100%\"><a href=\"https:\/\/www.scribd.com\/doc\/504010291\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" target=\"_blank\">View this document on Scribd<\/a><\/div><\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"DSnDHzD4Gw\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/09\/data-brokers-tracking\/\">Data brokers track everywhere you go, but their days may be numbered<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Data brokers track everywhere you go, but their days may be numbered” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/07\/09\/data-brokers-tracking\/embed\/#?secret=DSnDHzD4Gw\" data-secret=\"DSnDHzD4Gw\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<div class=\"embed breakout\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"5iFo4CFbBT\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/04\/20\/whos-funding-privacy-tech\/\">Who’s funding privacy tech?<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; readabilityObject.title: New privacy bill would end law enforcement practice of buying data from brokers
readabilityObject.content:
A new bill known as the Fourth Amendment is Not for Sale Act would seal up a loophole that intelligence and law enforcement agencies use to obtain troves of sensitive and identifying information to which they wouldn’t otherwise have legal access.

The new legislation, proposed by Senators Ron Wyden (D-OR) and Rand Paul (R-KY), would require government agencies to obtain a court order to access data from brokers. Court orders are already required when the government seeks analogous data from mobile providers and tech platforms.

“There’s no reason information scavenged by data brokers should be treated differently than the same data held by your phone company or email provider,” Wyden said. Wyden describes the loophole as a way that police and other agencies buy data to “end-run the Fourth Amendment.”

Paul criticized the government for using the current data broker loophole to circumvent Americans’ constitutional rights. “The Fourth Amendment’s protection against unreasonable search and seizure ensures that the liberty of every American cannot be violated on the whims, or financial transactions, of every government officer,” Paul said.

Critically, the bill would also ban law enforcement agencies from buying data on Americans when it was obtained through hacking, violations of terms of service or “from a user’s account or device.”

That bit highlights the questionable practices of Clearview AI, a deeply controversial tech company that sells access to a facial recognition search engine. Clearview’s platform collects pictures of faces scraped from across the web, including social media sites, and sells access to that data to police departments around the country and federal agencies like ICE.

In scraping their sites for data to sell, Clearview has run afoul of just about every major social media platform’s terms of service. Facebook, YouTube, Twitter, LinkedIn and Google have all denounced Clearview for using data culled from their services and some have even sent cease-and-desists ordering the data broker to stop.

The bill would also expand privacy laws to apply to infrastructure companies that own cell towers and data cables, seal up workarounds that allow intelligence agencies to obtain metadata from Americans’ international communications without review by a FISA court and ensure that agencies seek probable cause orders to obtain location and web browsing data.

The bill, embedded below, isn’t just some nascent proposal. It’s already attracted bipartisan support from a number of key co-sponsors, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Bernie Sanders on the Democratic side and Republicans Mike Lee and Steve Daines. A House version of the legislation was also introduced Wednesday.
